summary: New York Times article reporting Jeffrey Epstein's death by suicide in his Manhattan jail cell on August 10, 2019. The article details the circumstances of his death, his recent indictment on sex trafficking charges, his controversial 2008 plea deal, and his connections to numerous high-profile individuals.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Found dead by suicide in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan while awaiting trial on federal sex trafficking charges.

persons.name: William K. Rashbaum
persons.context: Co-author of the article covering Epstein's death and the surrounding circumstances.

persons.name: Benjamin Weiser
persons.context: Co-author of the article covering the Manhattan federal courts and Epstein's case.

persons.name: Michael Gold
persons.context: Co-author of the article reporting on Epstein's suicide.

persons.name: William P. Barr
persons.context: Issued a statement expressing being appalled by Epstein's death and announcing an FBI investigation and an Inspector General inquiry.

persons.name: Donald J. Trump

connections.description: Wexner was Epstein's biggest client, giving him vast authority to manage his personal fortune for about 16 years, which was the source of much of Epstein's wealth.
Mark is Jeffrey's younger brother and was described in a court memo as his only living immediate family member and that they were close.
Weingarten was part of Epstein's defense team in his federal sex trafficking case.

events.title: Epstein's Death in Jail
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead by suicide in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan at roughly 6:30 a.m.

events.title: Previous Suicide Attempt/Incident
events.description: Epstein was found unconscious in his jail cell with marks on his neck, investigated as a possible suicide attempt. He was placed on suicide watch after this.

events.title: Removed from Suicide Watch
events.description: Epstein was removed from suicide watch and returned to the special housing unit at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.

events.title: Arrest at Teterboro Airport
events.description: Epstein was arrested at Teterboro Airport in New Jersey after his private plane landed from Paris. He was charged with sex trafficking and sex trafficking conspiracy.

events.title: Florida Plea Deal
events.description: Epstein avoided federal charges by pleading guilty to state charges of solicitation of prostitution from a minor, serving 13 months in jail with work release privileges.

events.title: Release of Sealed Documents
events.description: A federal appeals court released a cache of previously sealed legal documents providing new details about activities inside Epstein's homes and recruitment of victims.

locations: Private island, United States Virgin Islands
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan on the morning of August 10, 2019.
Epstein had been removed from suicide watch on July 29, 2019, after being placed on it following a July 23 incident where he was found unconscious with neck marks.
Attorney General William Barr ordered an FBI investigation and an Inspector General inquiry into the circumstances of Epstein's death.
Epstein was arrested on July 6, 2019, on federal sex trafficking charges and faced up to 45 years in prison if convicted.
Much of Epstein's wealth was attributed to managing the personal fortune of retail billionaire Leslie Wexner, who later accused Epstein of misappropriating vast sums.
